column1: SOURCES: National Academy of Social Insurance estimates based on data received from state agencies, the Department of Labor, A.M. Best Company, and the National Council on Compensation Insurance.
column2:
NOTES: States periodically update prior-year data, and any such changes are included in the current table.
          Totals do not necessarily equal the sum of rounded components.
column3: a. The National Academy of Social Insurance has revised its estimates for 2009–2012. For details, see Appendix D, Workers' Compensation: Benefits, Coverage, and Costs, 2013 (https://www.nasi.org/research/2015/report-workers-compensation-benefits-coverage-costs-2013).
column4: b. Federal benefits include those paid under the Federal Employees' Compensation Act for civilian employees; the portion of the Black Lung benefit program that is financed by employers; and a portion of benefits under the Longshore and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act that are not reflected in state data, namely, benefits paid by self-insured employers and special funds under the LHWCA.
